Making the transition from print to multimedia

by Emily Kennard on December 16, 2010 · 9300 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F12%2F16%2Fmaking-the-transition-from-print-to-multimedia%2FMaking+the+transition+from+print+to+multimedia2010-12-16+10%3A00%3A08Emily+Kennardhttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D930

in College journalism,Digital media,Multimedia journalist,Training

My main journalistic background is in print. I’ve been writing since I can remember, and I became interested in print journalism as early as the fifth grade.

Multimedia journalism wasn’t brought to my attention until my sophomore year of college — nine years after my interest in the field of journalism began. When I first started using cameras and other equipment, I felt completely thrown out of my comfort zone.

Ian Shapira, a writer for the Washington Post, recently made this journey and also blogged about it.

Shapira said, “I discovered that making a compelling video . . . requires a fundamentally different kind of journalistic skill.”

I could not agree more. However, I’ve learned that video and audio can reveal elements of a story that print journalism cannot. It turns out that lugging around the equipment is worth the extra time and attention.

Below I provide a simple and practical list that print journalists might find helpful when delving into the multimedia world:

Make a list

When I go to report on something for a newspaper or magazine, all I need to worry about is my paper and pen. With multimedia, the list seems to go on forever. Is the shot white balanced? Do I have extra tapes? Do I have extra batteries? Is the shot in focus?

One of the worst feelings is conducting an hour-long interview or recording several hours of footage and then realizing the audio was wonky or the tripod wasn’t stable.

Make a list of all of these components before the interview. This way, you won’t forget anything. Check them off after you complete them and the foundation for your multimedia will always be consistent.

Make you sure you have all of the gear. You don’t want to arrive at an interview and forget your memory card or tapes. Make sure you’ve connected everything that can be prepared in advance. This way, you won’t have to waste time setting up equipment when you arrive.

Utilize the camera

Don’t use the camera for “wallpaper” shots; shots which don’t really show the audience anything. They are just there for the sake of being there. When I first started using cameras, my inclination was to get shots of anything and everything.

What I have found works is making a basic list of shots you think are useful to tell the story. Using this method, you won’t forget them if you get wrapped up in the interview. Of course, you should not feel tied down to this list and always seek to shoot more if you feel necessary.

Use your print background

I think having a sound reporting background is necessary and is an advantage in the multimedia field. Without this, how would you know which questions to ask in the interview? While the source is speaking, you should be thinking about which quotes are strong; which ones stand out. And then keep these quotes in mind when gathering your background footage. Don’t get lost in the visual world and lose a solid story.

Don’t be scared

This is the most important thing I can emphasize. Using a camera is foreign to print journalists. It’s okay. Embrace it. Ask questions. Experiment. Take too many shots. The best (and only) way to learn is by doing.

You won’t learn from merely listening to a lecture or reading about how to operate it. If you don’t go out into the field with the equipment, you will not learn.

In conclusion, going into the field with equipment might seem daunting. At first, it will be. But after a few times, you will start to feel comfortable.

And the more comfortable you feel, the more likely you are to produce better stories. And the best stories transcend any medium.

Emily Kennard, a senior from Cleveland, Ohio, is a multimedia journalist for the Reese Felts Digital News Project.

Quick, mobile news: live-streaming video from an iPhone 4

by Noel Cody on November 18, 2010 · 9271 commenthttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F11%2F18%2Fquick-mobile-news%2FQuick%2C+mobile+news%3A+live-streaming+video+from+an+iPhone+42010-11-18+22%3A55%3A51Noel+Codyhttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D927

in iPhone,Social media,Twitter

Live-streaming video isn’t new. Mobile technology isn’t new. But the ability to stream video in real-time from a smartphone has just now become widely available, and  we tried it for the first time this morning at reesenews.org.

We used an iPhone 4 to stream live video from the UNC-Chapel Hill Board of Trustees meeting at the Carolina Inn. While the board-members discussed a tuition increase and UNC-CH’s recent NCAA football investigation, I stood to the side of the room and shot video on the tiny device, surrounded by tripods and large news cameras from other local news organizations.

It was a strange experience — only a green light in the corner of the screen let me know I was streaming live. But the video ran from the phone, through a web service called Qik and onto a page at reesenews.org — and people watched. In about two hours, we received 93 views total, with an average of 9.19 minutes spent per view.

We did hit some snags.

At first, we tried to rely on the phone’s 3G connection, but the connection wasn’t strong enough and the video stream was choppy. We fell back on  the Carolina Inn’s wifi connection, but the connection was weak in some places in the room, and we had to move around before we found a spot with a strong signal. Next time, we’ll scout the location out beforehand.

While I filmed, Reese Felts Digital News Project multimedia reporter Rebecca Seawell live-tweeted from our Twitter account. This wasn’t the original plan — at first, Becca was going to simply stream live video. But when I went to troubleshoot connectivity issues, we decided that I should shoot while she typed.

Turns out the combination worked well – when the wifi signal became weak and the video stream went down, our audience could switch over to Twitter to continue to receive information. The live-tweets also allowed our audience to look back at information and quotes from earlier on in the meeting. Finally, we used the opportunity to cross-promote; we notified the live-stream viewers of our live-tweeting, and our Twitter followers of the live-stream. The combination of live text and live video worked well, and it’s something we’ll do again in the future, if possible.

The other news organizations in the room emerged with higher-quality video, no doubt about it.

But the iPhone 4 is a new tool for a new form of live, engaging news coverage.

We’re brainstorming new ways to use these mobile tool, and mobile live video is full of potential.

As we continue to seek new ways to bring news to the community and to engage our audience, we’ll aim to use the iPhone4 Qik video in new ways.

The reesenews jQuery weather widget 1.0

by Seth Wright on November 18, 2010 · 9223 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F11%2F18%2Fthe-reesenews-jquery-weather-widget-1-0%2FThe+reesenews+jQuery+weather+widget+1.02010-11-18+02%3A58%3A56Seth+Wrighthttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D922

in College journalism,Digital media,WordPress

reesenews 5-day forecast weather widget

See this widget in action at reesenews.org.

Click here to download all of the source files.

I often won’t click on weather widgets from news sites because they link away from the current page, and I didn’t want reesenews to have that same, tired style of weather. I wanted it to be a utility. And, I wanted it to give users what they are looking for instantly.

We discussed it amongst the team and ended up with a weather drop-down that is more sleek and up-to-date, which provides site visitors with an elegant drop-down menu. While the feature predominantly targets touch screens like the Apple iPad, it works for all users regardless of platform.

The first step to creating this weather drop-down was to get an XML document provided by Weather.com. I parsed this file using PHP SimpleXMLElement. I struggled with learning how to parse an XML document at first, and I saw that some people parsed XML using string searches. SimpleXMLElement is the quickest and easiest way to process an XML file using PHP. It allows you to sort through XML like you would an array.

Code Examples (double-click code to copy):

$data = file_get_contents($uri);
$weather = new SimpleXMLElement($data);
$hi_temperature = $weather->dayf->day[0]->hi;

This statement declares a JavaScript variable (below) called data that pulls the XML from the Weather.com API.

$uri

I then turn the data into a SimpleXMLElement, which allows it to be treated much like an array.

In PHP, to select array positions use the following characters:

->

I use the PHP echo language construct to add HTML from the PHP file. This creates the basic structure of the weather drop-down. There will be a box at the top, which displays the current temperature and corresponding weather icon:

#current_conditions

When the user clicks on this box, there will be another box that drops down:

#weatherDrawer

Resulting in three smaller boxes:

#weatherTop
#forecast
#weatherBottom

To include this PHP file in our index.php, where the rest of our code lies, make sure to wrap this statement inside PHP tags:

include 'weather.php'

The reason #weatherDrawer is made of three boxes is so that we can use CSS to create a menu feel. #weatherTop and #weatherBottom both have background-image set to a .png file and do not repeat. However, #forecast has a repeat-y and is only a few pixels high so all of the content can fill in as needed.

Finally, we need to program the jQuery action that creates the drop down effect of the weather drawer. First, I link the jQuery source file in the head of my document, and for convenience, I used an inline script:

$("div#weatherDrawer").hide();
$("div#current_conditions").click(
function () {
$("div#weatherDrawer").stop(true, true).slideToggle();
}
);

This script tells the #weatherDawer to be hidden initially. The three div’s inside the #weatherDrawer will each be hidden.

Then on the click of the current conditions, the weatherDrawer will slideToggle. SlideToggle is the animation effect built into jQuery that creates the drawer-like feel.

We’re happy to share the code and files to those who have expressed interest in how this weather experience was created. This work is licensed under Creative Commons with attribution. 

Source Files: reeseweather jquery widget 1.0 (217 kb)

Included Files:

  • images
  • index.php
  • jquery-1.4.2.js
  • ReadMe
  • weather-icons
  • weather.php

The sticky notes we use on reesenews.org are called “Office environment weather theme sticky note – File #: 9495357″ are from iStockPhoto.com and are available for purchase and download here.

Full Code (double-click to copy):


<?php
//Name: reesenews.org weather widget 1.0
//Description: A weather widget using the weather.com xml service, based on HTML, CSS, and JQuery.
//Copyright (C) 2010  Reese Felts Digital News Project - University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
//This program is free software: you can redistribute it and/or modify
//it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
//the Free Software Foundation, either version 3 of the License, or
//(at your option) any later version.

//This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
// but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
//MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
//GNU General Public License for more details.

// You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
//along with this program.  If not, see <a href="http://www.gnu.org/licenses/">GNU.org</a>.

//Contact Information:

//Reese Felts Digital News Project (reesenews.org)
// School of Journalism and Mass Communication
//University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
//11 Carroll Hall - CB 3365
//Cameron Avenue
//Chapel Hill, NC 27599
//Tel. 919-962-2017
//Web: http://www.reesefelts.org, http://www.reesenews.org
//Contact 1: Tony Zeoli, Lead Developer, email: tonyzeoli@reesnews.org
//Contact 2: Seth Wright, Platform Developer, email: sethwright@reesenews.org

//start weather widget
//set variables for URI of weather and area of the icons

 $imagelocation = "http://www.reesenews.org/wp-content/themes/reesenews/weather-icons/";
 $uri = 'http://xoap.weather.com/weather/local/27514?cc=*&dayf=5&link=xoap&prod=xoap&unit=s&par=1202937883&key=e62d2089516e379f';

 //parse the xml data from weather.com
 $data = file_get_contents($uri);
 $weather = new SimpleXMLElement($data);
 $location = $weather->loc->dnam;

 //check the current conditions
 $current_tmp = $weather->cc->tmp;
 $current_icon = $weather->cc->icon;
 $current_feels = $weather->cc->flik;
 $current_icon_href = $imagelocation . $current_icon . '.png';

 echo "<div id='current_conditions'>";
 printf("<span>%s&deg;</span> <img src='%s' />", $current_tmp, $current_icon_href);

 echo "</div>";

 echo '<div id="weatherDrawer">';

 echo '<div id="weatherTop"></div>';

 echo "<div id='forecast'>";
 //4 day loop diplaying the day, hi, low, and icon
 //setting i=1 means we are checking for tomorrow. 0 would be today.
 for($i=0; $i <= 4; $i++) {
 $day = $weather->dayf->day[$i]->attributes()->t;
 $dayShort = substr($day,0,3);

 //get the hi
 $hi = $weather->dayf->day[$i]->hi;

 //get the low
 $low = $weather->dayf->day[$i]->low;

 //get the icon
 $icon = $weather->dayf->day[$i]->part[0]->icon;

 $iconhref = $imagelocation . $icon . '.png';

 printf("<div class='weather'>");

 printf("<span class='red'>%s</span><br />", $dayShort);

 printf("<span class='black'>%s&deg;</span>", $hi);

 echo " <span class='black'>/</span> ";

 printf("%s&deg;<br />", $low);

 printf('<img src="%s" /><br /><br />', $iconhref);

 echo "</div>";
 }

 echo "</div>";

 echo '<div id="weatherBottom"></div>';

 echo '</div>';

?>

Seth Wright is Platform Developer for reesnews.org.

Seven days, and just the start

by Monty Cook on November 9, 2010 · 8830 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F11%2F09%2Fseven-days-and-just-the-start%2FSeven+days%2C+and+just+the+start2010-11-09+17%3A00%3A20Monty+Cookhttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D883

in College journalism,Digital media,iPhone,Newsroom,Social media,Twitter

Seven days.

Reesenews.org has been live as a news and information site for seven days. We’re already getting feedback from users, and metrics continue to track.

The site itself is in beta form. It’s still evolving and will be for months to come. We also have known issues that arise from the efforts to program, design and launch a student-run website from scratch in less than three months.

We’ve learned lessons in the first week about site production, search engine optimization, tagging and metadata, editing, quality control, corrections and clarifications, transparency, and when it is appropriate to unpublish content (answer: rarely).

And Adobe’s Sitecatalyst metrics and analytics service is providing early data.

22,586 page views. The most-viewed story? Shane Ryan’s piece on Halloween night on Franklin Street, “Meet Fred Flintstone and a host of revelers,” followed by “The Return of the Rat,” about the return of the Ramshead Rathskeller restaurant.

reesenews, Your Source for Election Coverage

by Noel Cody on November 1, 2010 · 8640 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F11%2F01%2Freesenews-your-source-for-election-coverage%2Freesenews%2C+Your+Source+for+Election+Coverage2010-11-01+20%3A09%3A10Noel+Codyhttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D864

in Politics

The candidates have taken a stand on the major issues, the political debates and campaign advertisements have almost come to an end and voters are ready to cast their ballots.

reesenews.org will offer original, detailed, up-to-date election coverage and analysis when political seats throughout North Carolina go up for grabs tomorrow. In addition to covering the state’s major elections, we’ll zoom in on the issues and elections happening right here in Orange County. We’ll be there as UNC students turn out to vote on campus, and we’ll let people from the community have their say on the issues they care about. And, of course, we’ll use multimedia, online tools, and social media to bring you the information quickly and effectively.
Stay informed, get involved, and make us your source for election coverage on Nov. 2.

The iPhone Challenge

by Monty Cook on October 26, 2010 · 8260 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F10%2F26%2Fthe-iphone-challenge%2FThe+iPhone+Challenge2010-10-26+14%3A56%3A37Monty+Cookhttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D826

in Apps,College journalism,Digital media,iPhone,Multimedia journalist,Training

Multimedia apps grouped for use on iPhones in the Digital Newsdesk Production class at UNC's School of Journalism and Mass Communication.

Students in the J463 Digital Newsdesk Production class have their mission: Produce a complete story package (text-photo-video-editing) using nothing more than an iPhone 4.

The due date for their project is Friday, but it also begins one piece of an experimental project without an end date. The Reese Felts Digital News Project at UNC’s School of Journalism and Mass Communication will test technology and platforms and explore their application for journalism. And in an age where anyone with a smartphone can commit an act of journalism just by shooting a photograph or a video of a news event and uploading, we wanted to look at turning backpack journalism into portable device journalism.

In addition to smartphones, we’ll be looking at tablet technology and social media platforms.

For the iPhone 4 project, students had to utilize the device’s 5-megapixel camera and 720p HD video camera, then rely on applications from Apple’s App Store for other reporting needs. And of course, phone calls to sources had to be made on the phone.

Using the phone for photos and video came easy. But editing video has proven to be a challenge. Not only are students editing in Apple’s iMovie app on the Multi-Touch interface, they’re doing it using their fingers.

“It’s challenging,” said Amanda Ruehlen, a senior from Concord, N.C. “You have to think about how you’re going to edit [in iMovie] as you shoot. You don’t have a luxury like you would in Final Cut [Pro] to put in multiple tracks. In Final Cut, you have more wiggle room. If the audio is bad, or the lighting is off, you know you can fix it in post-production. With the iPhone, you don’t have that option; at least not right now. I concentrated more on production with the iPhone than I did using the 5D [Canon EOS 5D Mark II] on a story earlier this semester.”

Stuart Scott won't Tweet this, but his advice is: write, research

by pressley baird on October 18, 2010 · 7223 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F10%2F18%2Fstuart-scott-wont-tweet-this-but-his-advice-is-write-research%2FStuart+Scott+won%26%23039%3Bt+Tweet+this%2C+but+his+advice+is%3A+write%2C+research2010-10-18+14%3A18%3A16pressley+bairdhttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.reesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D722

in Social media,Sports Journalism,Television

Stuart Scott on Twitter: "I do see how there is value, even when it comes to me and my job and my career, in having a Twitter page, driving our demographic toward what we’re doing." (ESPN photo)

Social media platforms, like Twitter, have become important tools for journalists. You can read headlines and news reports from around the world in real time, get an up-close look at how newspapers, television and radio stations cover those stories, and follow the updates of countless professional journalists.

But you can’t follow Stuart Scott, and you won’t be able to easily find out what he’s doing or thinking when he’s not on set for ESPN. He doesn’t have a Twitter or Facebook account.

I talked with Scott, a 1987 UNC graduate, anchor for ESPN’s SportsCenter and host of ESPN’s Monday Night Countdown, about the state of journalism and how social media plays a role. His view — even though he felt it was “old school” — still rings true in the age of digital everything.

PB: A lot of people nowadays say journalism is dead. What do you think about that?

SS: Journalism isn’t dead. Journalism has grown some appendages that didn’t used to be there. Some of them are really good, and some of them aren’t. I don’t think that blogs that talk about people and don’t rely on fact or research or any type of truth — that’s not journalism. But that is passing for journalism with a lot of people. And the problem is, that kind of non-journalism is passing for journalism with a lot of entities that are journalistic, if that makes sense. Places that are respectful and do it the right way often rely on blogs that don’t do it the right way. It’s grown appendages. It has changed, it has varied. But there’s no way that it’s dead. Because the essence of what we do still is write, is research.

The great disconnect

by tony zeoli on October 15, 2010 · 6740 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F10%2F15%2Fthe-great-disconnect%2FThe+great+disconnect2010-10-15+18%3A14%3A40tony+zeolihttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.reesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D674

in Citizen journalism,College journalism,Multimedia journalist,Television,Training,WordPress

Every day, millions of people around the world log on to myriad popular and niche websites or mobile applications to send emails and documents, post and share stories, upload images and videos, or chat with family, friends, and colleagues.

Popular web services like Facebook, Twitter, flickr, and YouTube give anyone the ability to publish content instantaneously, starting the conversation or adding to an existing one. We can communicate in a very public way to someone on the other side of the planet in less time than it takes to write this sentence. In sharing our lives through text, photo, audio and video, we have the ability to create and disseminate multimedia journalism.

Using a Flip® video camera, a proud family can take a video of their newborn seconds after birth, post the video to YouTube, and send the link to proud new grandparents. The family, reporting the birth of a child to relatives and friends instantaneously, is creating news in the same way that newspapers once printed birth announcements.

Another family, publishing the photos of a family camping trip to flickr, can be shared into Facebook by linking the two accounts. Or, they can be added directly to the photo gallery of a private Facebook group consisting of extended family members. Shooting these photos, then converting them with Photoshop or another image editing program and uploading them is multimedia production. Journalism comes into play by providing context for those images in the form of captions, and then informing everyone in the group of their existence.

In 1991, George Holliday videotaped what would become one of the most explosive examples of police brutality in American history. News outlets around the world broadcast the video recording of LAPD officers beating Rodney King after a high-speed chase through the streets of Los Angeles. This episode is a perfect example of the how citizen journalism can speak truth to power.

[click to continue…]

Amy Costello: 'As you build a career as a reporter … your name should mean something'

by jonathan michels on October 13, 2010 · 6306 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F10%2F13%2Fa-conversation-with-amy-costello%2FAmy+Costello%3A+%26%23039%3BAs+you+build+a+career+as+a+reporter+...+your+name+should+mean+something%26%23039%3B2010-10-13+14%3A53%3A42jonathan+michelshttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.reesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D630

in College journalism,Radio,Television

On her website, AmyCostello.com, Amy describes her multi-platform reporting experience simply: "Radio. Television. Podcasts. Web."

It’s less than a year until graduation. Some students are cringing at the idea of getting out into the fragmented world of modern journalism. But seasoned reporter Amy Costello says it’s never a bad time to be a journalist.

Amy has reported for National Public Radio and PRI’s The World. She’s also produced three documentaries for the PBS television program FRONTLINE/World. Her reporting from Darfur earned her an Emmy nomination.

To me, she’s the model of what the modern journalist should be. She’s capable, independent and can work on a wide range of platforms. I talked to Amy about her reporting, where journalism might be headed, and I got plenty of tips that every reporter can use.

JM: You worked for a number of years as a reporter and producer for public radio. How did you end up producing documentaries for FRONTLINE/World?

AC: I worked as a producer for NPR in Washington for three years. I then decided to take a leave of absence in order to visit South Africa, which is where my husband is from. After a few months in Cape Town, we decided to remain there permanently. So I quit my job at NPR and filed my first radio story from South Africa for a radio program called “Marketplace”. After my first story was broadcast, my editor asked me to go to Zimbabwe to cover the violent farm seizures that were going on there.

I was delighted and surprised how quickly my foreign correspondent career had begun. Over the course of the next few years, I traveled all over Africa for “Marketplace” and later for public radio program “The World”. Eventually, I made a trip to Boston to meet with a producer from the PBS television program, “FRONTLINE/World”. I was planning to travel to Darfur to report some radio stories on the mass killings there and FRONTLINE/World agreed to send a camerawoman along with me so that I could do a story for television, too. I had never done TV reporting before but I think my background in radio helped me as I made the transition to a new medium.

[click to continue…]

Enter our photo contest

by noel cody on October 12, 2010 · 6240 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesefelts.org%2F2010%2F10%2F12%2Fenter-our-photo-contest%2FEnter+our+photo+contest2010-10-12+19%3A41%3A21noel+codyhttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.reesefelts.org%2F%3Fp%3D624

in Social media

We’re launching a photo contest on our Facebook page this week, as part of our commitment to focus on and highlight viewpoints from the community. We invite participants to submit photos, beginning today, for a chance to win an iPod Nano or Amazon Kindle, and to have their work featured on reesenews when the site launches on Nov 1.

The contest will include four photo categories, one for each of the next four weeks.

This week, we’re asking for images of what “community” means to you. What visually represents community in your life? What defines community for Chapel Hill and the University? In future weeks, we’ll ask for photographs focusing on or representing a good cause, Carolina, and innovation.

We will be accepting submissions until Nov 1. Submissions are accepted through Flickr, or by e-mail. Find out how to submit your photos, and more information about the contest, at our Facebook page here.
